1. There was once a baby show among the Animals in the forest. 2. Of course all the proud mammas from far and near brought their babies. 3. Jupiter provided the prize. 4. But none got there earlier than Mother Monkey. 5. Proudly she presented her baby among the other contestants.

1. A little hungry Mouse found his way one day into a basket of corn. 2. He had to squeeze himself a good deal to get through the narrow opening between the strips of the basket. 3. Indeed he became about three times as big around the middle as he was when he went in. 4. When at last he had succeeded, he gorged himself to bursting. 5. But the corn was tempting and the Mouse was determined to get in.

1. One day a shepherd discovered a fat Pig in the meadow where his Sheep were pastured. 2. But in spite of its squeals and struggles to escape, the Shepherd tucked his prize under his arm and started off to the butcher's in the market place. 3. He very quickly captured the porker, which squealed at the top of its voice the moment the Shepherd laid his hands on it. 4. You would have thought, to hear the loud squealing, that the Pig was being cruelly hurt.

1. A Wild Boar was sharpening his tusks busily against the stump of a tree, when a Fox happened by. 2. So he made a great show of looking anxiously about, as if in fear of some hidden enemy. 3. Now the Fox was always looking for a chance to make fun of his neighbors. 4. But the Boar kept right on with his work.

1. A Bear roaming the woods in search of berries happened on a fallen tree in which a swarm of Bees had stored their honey. 2. Guessing what the Bear was after, the Bee flew at him, stung him sharply and then disappeared into the hollow log. 3. The Bear began to nose around the log very carefully to find out if the Bees were at home. 4. Just then one of the swarm came home from the clover field with a load of sweets.

Never before that night had I felt the extent of my own powers—of my sagacity.

In their gray visions they obtain glimpses of eternity, and thrill, in awakening, to find that they have been upon the verge of the great secret. 3. They penetrate, however, rudderless or compassless into the vast ocean of the “light ineffable,” and again, like the adventures of the Nubian geographer, “agressi sunt mare tenebrarum, quid in eo esset exploraturi.” 6. They who dream by day are cognizant of many things which escape those who dream only by night.

I repeat that in landscape arrangements alone is the physical nature susceptible of exaltation, and that, therefore, her susceptibility of improvement at this one point, was a mystery I had been unable to solve. 4. He thus explained:—Admit the earthly immortality of man to have been the first intention. 5. The disturbances were the preparations for his subsequently conceived deathful condition. 6. It was Ellison who suggested that they were prognostic of death. 7. My own thoughts on the subject had rested in the idea that the primitive intention of nature would have so arranged the earth’s surface as to have fulfilled at all points man’s sense of perfection in the beautiful, the sublime, or the picturesque; but that this primitive intention had been frustrated by the known geological disturbances—disturbances of form and color—grouping, in the correction or allaying of which lies the soul of art.

1. “The author’s observations on the artificial style,” continued Ellison, “are less objectionable. 2. There may be an object in keeping with the principle—an object unattainable by the means ordinarily possessed by individuals, yet which, if attained, would lend a charm to the landscape-garden far surpassing that which a sense of merely human interest could bestow. 3. It will be seen that, in bringing about such result, he secures all the advantages of interest or design, while relieving his work of the harshness or technicality of the worldly art. 4. This is just; as also is the reference to the sense of human interest. 5. In the most rugged of wildernesses—in the most savage of the scenes of pure nature—there is apparent the art of a creator; yet this art is apparent to reflection only; in no respect has it the obvious force of a feeling. 6. The principle expressed is incontrovertible—but there may be something beyond it. 7. A mixture of pure art in a garden scene adds to it a great beauty. 8. A poet, having very unusual pecuniary resources, might, while retaining the necessary idea of art or culture, or, as our author expresses it, of interest, so imbue his designs at once with extent and novelty of beauty, as to convey the sentiment of spiritual interference. 9. Now let us suppose this sense of the Almighty design to be one step depressed—to be brought into something like harmony or consistency with the sense of human art—to form an intermedium between the two:—let us imagine, for example, a landscape whose combined vastness and definitiveness—whose united beauty, magnificence, and strangeness, shall convey the idea of care, or culture, or superintendence, on the part of beings superior, yet akin to humanity—then the sentiment of interest is preserved, while the art intervolved is made to assume the air of an intermediate or secondary nature—a nature which is not God, nor an emanation from God, but which still is nature in the sense of the handiwork of the angels that hover between man and God.”

1. I was especially fond of animals, and was indulged by my parents with a great variety of pets. 2. This peculiarity of character grew with my growth, and in my manhood, I derived from it one of my principal sources of pleasure. 3. There is something in the unselfish and self-sacrificing love of a brute, which goes directly to the heart of him who has had frequent occasion to test the paltry friendship and gossamer fidelity of mere Man. 4. To those who have cherished an affection for a faithful and sagacious dog, I need hardly be at the trouble of explaining the nature or the intensity of the gratification thus derivable. 5. From my infancy I was noted for the docility and humanity of my disposition. 6. My tenderness of heart was even so conspicuous as to make me the jest of my companions. 7. With these I spent most of my time, and never was so happy as when feeding and caressing them.
